metadata.titleEn: Fengyun-4A satellite full disk hourly seamless land surface temperature dataset (2019-2023.6)
metadata.description: 1. Data content: This data includes 24-hour surface temperature data under the full disk of Fengyun-4A satellite, as well as quality identification data. The time range is from June 2018 to June 2023, providing long-term high-resolution surface temperature data. 2. Data source and processing method: The data is sourced from the website of the National Satellite Meteorological Center and processed using the surface energy balance method to obtain a dataset. 3. Data quality description: For quality control data QC, when QC=-1, the pixel is the fill value, when QC=0, the pixel is the sunny temperature, and when QC=1, the pixel is the cloudy temperature. 4. Achievements and Prospects of Data Application: This data and method have been published in a paper titled "Estimating Hourly All Weather Land Surface Temperature From FY-4A/AGRI Imagery Using the Surface Energy Balance Theory" in IEEE TRANSACTions ON GEOSCIENCE AND REMOTE SENSING
metadata.instructions: File Name: The all-weather surface temperature data is stored in HDF format. The file name is "ELITE.LST. seamless. FY4A-AGRI. yyyyddhhmm. V1.0. hdf", where yyyy represents the year and ddd represents the Julian date. For example, 2019001 represents this HDF file that describes the surface temperature distribution of the entire disk of Fengyun-4A satellite on the first day of 2019.

background: Land surface temperature (LST) drives the thermal exchange processes for land–atmosphere interactions and has been recognized as one of the essential climate variables (ECVs) for its key role in the study of climate change and Earth system science. Generally, we can obtain LST by ground measurement, land surface modeling, and satellite remote sensing. The retrieval of LST from satellite thermal infrared (TIR) observations has achieved great success, and many well-known LST products have been produced and freely released to the public. However, cloudy-sky conditions, which account for more than half of the actual weather on the global scale, block TIR sensors from receiving ground signals. Microwave remote sensing is also an effective way of estimating LST, especially under cloudy-sky conditions, but the spatial resolution and accuracy of microwave LST are inferior to that of the TIR LST; even microwave remote sensing can obtain LST under all-weather conditions. Since LST exhibits rapid diurnal variation linked to the land–atmosphere energy exchange and the water cycle, TIR data with the high temporal resolution offered by geostationary satellite sensors have a tremendous advantage in monitoring diurnal LST variations.
research objective: This study proposed an effective method to estimate hourly all-weather LST from the Advanced Geosynchronous Radiation Imager (AGRI) data under the framework of surface energy balance (SEB) theory. This study provides a promising solution to generate diurnal hourly all-weather LST for AGRI and other geostationary satellites.
challenges: Cloud cover obstructs TIR signals and leads to missing gaps that generally account for more than 50% of TIR LST maps. The interpolation methods may have large uncertainties in reconstructing the LST of large-scale spatial and/or temporal gaps. Furthermore, the reconstructed LST is typically the hypothetical cloud-free LST, in which a nonnegligible bias will be introduced due to the absence of the cloud radiative effects (CREs).
methods: An improved temperature and emissivity separation algorithm was first used to obtain the high-quality clear-sky LST, which plays a decisive role in ensuring the accuracy of recovered cloudy-sky LST. Then, we proposed a unique way to solve the temperature difference (1LST) between the cloudy-sky LST and hypothetical clear-sky LST caused by cloud radiative effects (CREs).
dataset: The AGRI L1 full disk TIR data, cloud mask product, and the Modern-Era Retrospective analysis for Research and Applications version 2 (MERRA-2) data [49] were used to retrieve clear-sky LST with the developed AGRI iTES algorithm. Other satellite data include: 1) the Global LAnd Surface Satellite (GLASS) surface Broadband Emissivity (BBE) product [51], [52], the leaf area index (LAI) product [53], and the blue-sky albedo climatology product [54]; 2) the MODIS NDVI product, the land cover product, the snow coverage product, and the cloud mask product; 3) the Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) LST product; and 4) the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) digital elevation model (DEM) data. ERA5 provides the surface single-level dataset with spatial–temporal resolutions of 0.25 ◦ and 1 h, respectively [55], from which we extracted the spatiotemporally continuous surface radiation (SURFRAD) components [DSR, DLR, and upward longwave radiation (ULR)] under all-weather and/or hypothetical clear-sky conditions. To validate the derived all-weather LST, the site measured surface longwave fluxes collected from 15 flux sites in the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER, http://data.tpdc.ac.cn/) network [57], [58], the Cold and Arid Research Network of Lanzhou University (CARN, http://data.tpdc.ac.cn/), and the Australian and New Zealand flux tower network (OzFlux, http://www.ozflux.org.au/) [59] were employed in this study.
findings: The bias and root mean squared error (RMSE) of the estimated AGRI hourly cloudy-sky LST are 0.10 K and 3.71 K during the daytime, and −0.20 K and 2.73 K during the nighttime, respectively. The overall bias (RMSE) of the estimated AGRI all-weather LST is 0.02 K (2.84 K). The estimated hourly all-weather LST not only captures the rapid variation in diurnal LST but is also promising for temporal upscaling. The temporally upscaled daily mean LST shows a bias (RMSE) of 0.03 K (1.35 K).

Definition.Question: What is a cloud mask product, and how does it enhance the quality of land surface temperature datasets?
Definition.Answer: A cloud mask product is a type of data used to identify and separate cloudy pixels from clear-sky pixels in satellite imagery. This is critical for enhancing the quality of land surface temperature (LST) datasets, as clouds can obstruct thermal infrared signals and introduce gaps or inaccuracies in the data. By using a cloud mask, researchers can apply algorithms to retrieve high-quality clear-sky LST and address the temperature differences caused by cloud radiative effects.

Comparison.Question: How does the method for estimating hourly all-weather land surface temperature using the surface energy balance theory compare to traditional ground measurement techniques in terms of data accuracy and resolution?
Comparison.Answer: The method for estimating hourly all-weather land surface temperature using the surface energy balance theory leverages satellite remote sensing to provide high temporal resolution data, particularly under cloudy-sky conditions, which is typically challenging for traditional ground measurements. Ground measurements, while potentially offering high accuracy at specific points, may not capture the spatial variability and rapid diurnal changes effectively like satellite methods.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data quality control between datasets derived from geostationary satellite sensors and those obtained from microwave remote sensing under all-weather conditions?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets derived from geostationary satellite sensors, such as those using thermal infrared data, often face challenges with cloud cover that obstructs signals, requiring sophisticated algorithms to estimate clear-sky conditions. On the other hand, microwave remote sensing can penetrate clouds but typically offers lower spatial resolution and accuracy compared to thermal infrared methods, leading to a different set of quality control challenges.

Interpretation.Question: What are the main challenges in reconstructing land surface temperature data under cloudy-sky conditions, and how can they be addressed to improve data continuity and accuracy?
Interpretation.Answer: The main challenges include cloud cover obstructing TIR signals and leading to large-scale spatial and temporal gaps in data. These can be addressed by using methods like improved temperature and emissivity separation algorithms, and solving the temperature differences caused by cloud radiative effects, which ensure accurate recovery of cloudy-sky LST and continuity in the dataset.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the surface energy balance theory be applied to enhance the interpretation of land surface temperature data collected from geostationary satellites?
Interpretation.Answer: Surface energy balance theory can be applied to estimate all-weather LST by considering the energy exchange between land and atmosphere, enabling the generation of diurnal hourly LST. This method helps in capturing rapid variations in LST due to diurnal cycles, providing a more comprehensive understanding of thermal exchanges and improving temporal upscaling capabilities.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for developing a method to estimate hourly all-weather land surface temperature from satellite data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need arises from the challenge that cloudy-sky conditions block thermal infrared (TIR) sensors from receiving ground signals, leading to missing gaps in land surface temperature (LST) data. These conditions account for more than half of the actual weather globally, necessitating an approach that can estimate LST under all-weather conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do interpolation methods introduce uncertainties when reconstructing land surface temperature over large-scale spatial or temporal gaps?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Interpolation methods introduce uncertainties because they may not accurately reconstruct the LST in the presence of cloud cover, which leads to a nonnegligible bias by neglecting cloud radiative effects (CREs) during the reconstruction process.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the development of a unique method for solving the temperature difference between cloudy-sky and clear-sky land surface temperatures?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The development of a unique method is driven by the need to address the temperature difference caused by cloud radiative effects (CREs), which affect the accuracy of the LST under cloudy conditions. An improved temperature and emissivity separation algorithm is used to ensure high-quality clear-sky LST, which is crucial for recovering the cloudy-sky LST accurately.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using a surface energy balance method for estimating hourly all-weather land surface temperature on data accuracy and coverage?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a surface energy balance method allows for the estimation of land surface temperature under all-weather conditions, thus overcoming the limitations posed by cloud cover on thermal infrared sensors. This approach significantly improves data coverage and accuracy, as it reduces the bias introduced by cloud radiative effects and captures rapid diurnal variations in temperature.

Causal Consequence.Question: What impact does the use of different satellite products, such as MODIS NDVI and ASTER LST, have on the development of methodologies for estimating land surface temperature?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of different satellite products like MODIS NDVI and ASTER LST supports the development of robust methodologies by providing diverse data inputs that can be used to refine temperature retrieval algorithms. These datasets contribute to improved spatial resolution and accuracy, allowing for more precise estimation of land surface temperature by addressing the challenges posed by varying land cover and atmospheric conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a data collection method that estimates hourly all-weather land surface temperature using geostationary satellite sensors?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to overcome the limitations of traditional thermal infrared sensors, which cannot capture data under cloudy conditions, thus providing a complete and continuous dataset for monitoring diurnal land surface temperature variations and enhancing the understanding of land-atmosphere energy exchanges.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of employing the surface energy balance theory in the data processing approach for land surface temperature retrieval?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to generate accurate hourly all-weather land surface temperature data by accounting for the effects of cloud cover, which allows for the estimation of temperature differences between cloudy and clear-sky conditions and improves the overall reliability of the dataset.

It includes a temperature and emissivity separation algorithm to obtain high-quality clear-sky LST and a unique way to solve the temperature difference between cloudy-sky LST and hypothetical clear-sky LST caused by cloud radiative effects.

Enablement.Answer: The improved temperature and emissivity separation algorithm enables the retrieval of high-quality clear-sky LST, which is crucial for ensuring the accuracy of the recovered cloudy-sky LST. This method plays a decisive role in the data collection process.

Expectation.Question: Why might challenges arise in accurately reconstructing land surface temperature data from satellite thermal infrared observations under cloudy conditions?
Expectation.Answer: Cloud cover obstructs thermal infrared signals, causing missing data that generally account for more than 50% of the thermal infrared land surface temperature maps. This results in large uncertainties when interpolation methods are used to reconstruct the temperature data, introducing nonnegligible biases due to the absence of cloud radiative effects.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential reasons for the uncertainties in estimating land surface temperature using microwave remote sensing compared to thermal infrared remote sensing?
Expectation.Answer: While microwave remote sensing can estimate land surface temperature under all-weather conditions, its spatial resolution and accuracy are inferior to those of thermal infrared remote sensing. This is due to the inherent limitations in microwave technology compared to the higher temporal resolution and accuracy available through thermal infrared sensors.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to consider the surface energy balance theory when estimating hourly all-weather land surface temperature from satellite data?
Expectation.Answer: The surface energy balance theory provides a framework for accurately estimating the temperature difference between cloudy-sky and hypothetical clear-sky conditions, addressing the biases introduced by cloud radiative effects. This method ensures a more reliable estimation of land surface temperature, capturing rapid diurnal variations and enabling temporal upscaling.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using cloud radiative effects to adjust land surface temperature estimations in the presence of clouds?
Judgmental.Answer: Cloud cover obstructs thermal infrared signals, leading to missing gaps in LST maps, which can account for more than 50% of the data. Interpolating these gaps introduces uncertainties, and the hypothetical cloud-free LST often carries a bias due to the absence of cloud radiative effects. Solving for the temperature difference caused by these effects is critical to ensure accurate LST estimation.
